fful faste he caste how al this myght stonde.
Loue hym made al prest to don hir bide.
Or rather deyen than she shulde go.
But reson seyde hym on þat oother syde.
without assent of hir ne do nat so.
Yif thow debate it liste she be thy foo.
And seyn þat thorwgh thi medelynge is Iblowe.
Yowre bother loue ther it was erst vnknowe.
Of which he gan deliberen for the beste.
That though the lordes wolde al she wente.
He wolde late hem graunte what hem liste.
And telle his lady first what they mente.
And whan þat she hadde seide hym hir entente.
Theraftir wolde he werken also bylyue.
Theygh al the world ayein it wolde stryue.
Ector which þat wel the grekys herde.
ffor Antenor how they wolde han Criseide.
Gan it withstonde / and sobrelich answerde.
Sire she nys no prisoner he seyde.
I not on yow who þat this charge leyde.
But on my parte ye may eftsoone hem telle.
we ne vsen her no wymmen for to selle.
The noyse of poeple vp sterte than at onys.
As breme / as blase of straw Iset on fire.
ffor in fortnne it wolde for the nonys.
They sholden hir confusioun desire.
Ector quod they what goost may yow enspire.
This womman thus to shilde and don vs leese.
Daun Antenor / a wrong weye now ye cheese.
That is so wys / and ek so bold baroun.
And we han nede of folk as men may se.
He is eke oon the grettest of this towne.
O. Ector lat tho fantasies be.
O kyng Priam quod they thus syggen we.
That al oure voys is to forgon Criseide.
And to deliueren antenor they preyde.
O Iuuenal lord soth it is thy sentence.
That litel witen folk what is to yerne.
That they ne fynde in hir desir offence.
ffor cloude of errour lat hem nat discerne.
what best / and lo her ensaumple as yerne.
This folk desiron now deliuerance.
Of Antenor / þat broughte hem to meschance.
ffor he was after traytour to þat town.
Of Troye / allas they quyte hym to rathe.
O nyce world / lo thy discrecioun.
Criseide which þat neuere dede hem scathe.
Shal now no lenger in hir blisse bathe.
But Antenor he shal com hom to towne.
And she shal out thus seiden heere and howne.
ffor which delivered was by parlament
ffor Antenor to yelden out Criseide.
And hit pronouncede by the president.
Altheygh þat Ector nay ful ofte preyde.
What fynaly what wight þat it withseide.
It was for naught / it moste ben and sholde.
ffor substaunce of the parlement it wolde.
Departed out of parlament echone.
This Troilus withoute wordes mo.
Into his chaumbre spedde hym faste allone.
But yif it were a man of his or two.
The whiche he bad out faste for to go.
Bycause he wolde slepyn as he seyde.
And hastely vpon his bedde hym leyde.
And as in wynter leuys ben biraft.
Ech aftir oother til the tre be bare.
So þat ther nys but barke and braunch Ilaft.
Lith Troilus biraft of ech welfare.
Ibounden in the blake barke of care.
Disposed wood out of his wit to breyde.
So soore hym sat the chaungynge of Criseide.
He rist vp and euery dore he shette.
And wyndow ek / and tho this sorwful man.
Vpon his beddesside adown hym sette.
fful like a ded ymage pale and wan.
And in his brest the heped wo bigan.
Out breste / and he to werken in this wyse.
In his woodnesse. as I shal yow dewyse.
Right as the wylde boole bygynneth sprynge.
Now her now there Idarted to the herte.
And of hise wo rorith in compleynige.
Right so gan he abouthe chaumbre sterte.
Smytynge his brest ay with his fistes smerte.
His hed to the wal his body to the grounde.
fful ofte he swapte himseluen to confounde.
Hise eyen two for piete of herte.
Out stremeden as swifte welles tweye.
The heyghe sobbes of hise sorwes smerte.
His speche hym refte vnnethes myght he seye.
O deth allas / whi nyltow do me dye.
Acorsed be that day whiche þat nature.
Shoop me to ben a lyues creature.
But aftir whan the furye and alle this rage.
which þat his herte twiste and faste threste.
By lengthe of tyme somwhat gan aswage.
Vpon his bed he leyde hym don to reste.
But tho biganne hise teeris moore out breste.
That wondir is the body may suffise.
To half this wo which þat I yow deuyse.
Than seide he thus / fortune allas the while.
what haue .I. don / what haue I thus agilt.
How myghtestow for routhe me bigile.
Is ther no grace / and shal I thus be spilt.
Shal thus Criseide awey / for that thow wilt.
Allas how maystow in thy herte fynde.
To ben to me thus cruel and vnkynde.
Haue I the naught honoured al my lyue.
As thow wel woste aboue the goddes alle.
why wiltow me fro Ioye thus depryue.
O. Troilus what may men the calle.
But wrechche of wrechches out of honour falle.
Into miserie / in which I wol bywaille.
Criseide allas / til þat the breth me faille.
Allas fortune yif þat my lif in Ioye.
Displesed hadde vnto thy foul enuye.
why ne haddestowe my fadir kynge of Troye.
Biraft the lif / or don my brothren dye.

But euere mo lo this is thy manere.
So reue a wight þat most is to hym deero.
To proeue in that thy gerful violence.

O verrey lord. o loue .o. god allas.
Thow knowest best myn herte and al my thoughte.
what shal my sorowful lif don in this cas.

On lyue / in torment and in cruel peyne.
This infortune. or this disauenture.
Allone as I was born Iwys compleyne.

Santipe Sarpedon̄ Polinestor
Polite and eke the troian̄ dan̄ Ruphes
And other lee folk as phebuosos
For al Ector so that the folk of Troye
Drede the lese a gret part of hir loye
To pryamus whas yeven̄ at his Requeste
A tyme of trew. And tho they gan̄ to trete
hir prysonners to chaungen̄ mest and leste
And for to sourplus yeuen̄ sommes grete
This this thing was cowde a-non̄ in euery strete
Bothe in thassege in tovne and euery where
And with the first. it com̄ to Calcas ere
Whan̄ Calcas knewe this traitte shulde falle
I consistorye a-monges the grekes soone
he gan̄ in thringe. fortħ with lordes olde
And sette hym there as he was wont to donne
And with a ianged face he badde a bone
For loue of gode to that Reuerence
To stynte noyse And yeue hym Audience
Than̄ seide he thus. loo lordes Icħ was
Troian̄ as it is knowen̄ oute of drede
And yif that ye Remembre I am Calcas
That altherfist. yaf comfort to your nede
And tolde wel how that ye shulden spede
For dredles thoro you shal in a stounde
Be troye ybrent. and betyn̄ dovn̄ to grounde
Or in what fourme or in what maner wyse
This toune to shende. and al your lyst to cheue
Ye haue me herde or this you devise
This knowen̄ ye. my lordes as I leue
[Omitted in Harl. 1239. No gap for it.]
I come my-selfen̄ in my propre persone
To teche in this how you is best to doone
Having vnto my treysour And my Rente
Rygħt no Resport. to Respecte of your ese
Thus al my gode. I lefte and to you wente
wenynge in this my lordes you to plese
But Al this losse dothe me no disese
I vouchesaf. as wysly I haue ioye
For you to lose al that I haue in troye
Saue a dougħter that I lefte Allas
Sleping At home whan̄ oute of troye I sterte
O sterne O cruel fadur that I was
how myght I haue in that so harde an̄ herte
Allas I ne hade brought hir in hir sherte
For sorow of wych I wyl not lyue to morow
But yif ye my lordes Rewe on̄ my sorow
For by that [that overlined later.] cause I sawe now tyme or now
For to deliueren Ich [MS. Ioh] holde haue my pees
For now or neuer yif it like you
I may hyr haue Ryght soone or doutles
O helpe And grace a-monge al this prees
Rewe on̄ this olde Kaytyf in distresse
Sithen I thurgħ you haue Al this distresse
Ȝee haue now caugħt and fetred in pryson̄
Troyans y-now. And yif your wylles be
My chylde wych. may haue Redempcion
Now for the loue of gode and of bounte
Oon̄ of so fele Allas so yeue hym me
What nede were it. this prayer where to werne
Syn̄ ye shal haue. bothe folkis And tovne as yerne
On peryl on̄ my lyf hit shal not lye
Apollo hatħ me folde. feythfully
I haue eke founden̄. by Astronymye
By sorte And of Augury trewly
And dar wel I say that tyme is faste by
That fyre And fflame on̄ Al that the tovn̄ shal sprede
And thus shal Troye turne in to Asshen̄ dede
For certein Phebus And neptunus Also
That maden the [the over line.] walles of the tovne
Ben̄ Alwey wyth folke of Troye to wrothe
They wyll it eft. bringe to confusion̄
Ryght for despite of kynge lamedon̄
Be cause ne nolde paye hem hyr hyre
The tovne shal yit be sette vppon̄ a fyre
Tellyng this tale Alwey this olde grey
Humble in his speche And in his loke eke
The salt terys from̄ hys eyen̄ tweyn̄
Ful fast ran̄ dovn̄. by eyther cheke
So longe he gan̄. of socour hem by-seche
That for to hele hym̄. of hys sykes sore
They yafe hym̄ Antenor wythouten more
But who was glade y-nough but Calcas tho
And of this thinges ful sone his nedes glade
On hem that shulde for tretys goo
And hem ful ofte specyally preyde
For Antenor to bringe home Creseide
And whan̄ pryam̄ his sone gan̄ sende
Thambassedours streyght to Troye wende
The cause y-tolde of hyr commynge the olde
Pryam̄ the kynge. ful sone in general
lete hervpon̄ hys parlement to holde
Of wych theffecte to you Rehersyn shal
Them-bassadours ben̄ Answerd for final
Theschange of prysonners And Al this nede
hem̄ lyketh wel. and forthe in̄ they procede
This troilus was present in this place
Whan̄ axed was Antenor for Creseide
For wych ful soon̄ changen̄ gan̄ his face
As he that wyth the wordes wel nygh deyde
But natheles he to hit no worde sede
Lest men̄ shulde his Affection̄ espie
With mannes hert he gan̄ his sorowes drye
And fuɫɫ of Anguyssħ And of grysly drede
A-bode what other lordes wolde sey
And yf they wolde graunte as god forbede
Theschange of hyr than̄ thogh he thinges twey
First how to saue hir honour And in that wey
Myght best theschange of hir withstonde
Ful faste he caste how al this myght stande
loue hym̄ made Al prest to doon̄ hyr byde
Or Rather dyen̄ than̄ she shulde goo
But Reson̄ seide hym̄ on̄ that other syde
With-outen̄ the Assent of hyr do not soo
yif you debate it lest she be thy foo
And sey that thurgħ thy medelynge is y-blow
your brother loue ther it was erst vnknowe
For wyche he gan̄ delybren̄ for the best
That thogh the lordes wolden̄ that she wente
he wolde lete hem̄. graunte what hem̄ lyste
And telle hys lady fyrst what that they mente
And whan̄ that she hade seide hym̄ hir entente
Ther-After wolde he werken̄ Also blyue
Thogħ Al the worlde a-yeine it wolde stryue
Ector wyche that Wele the grekys Herde
For Antenor how they wolde haue Creseyde
Gan it withstonde. And soubrely answerde
I not who on̄ you thys charge leyde [These lines inverted in Harl. 1239.]
Syres she is no prysonner he seide1
But on̄ my parte. ye efte-sone hym telle
Whe vsen̄ here / no womān for to selle
The noyse of the peple / than̄ vpstynt At onys
As breme as blasse / of sorow. y-sette A-fyre
For Infortune / it wolde for the nones
They shulde hyr confusyon̄ desyre
Ector quod they / what gost may you enspire
This womman thus to shelde and doon vs lese
Dain [or Dam] Antenor / A wronge wey ye chese
That so wyse / And eke so boulde a baroun̄
And whe haue nede. of folkis as men̄ may see
He is eke oon̄. the grettest of this tovn̄
O ector. lat that fantasye bee
O kynge Pryam̄. thus sey we
That al oure voyce. is for to goon̄ Creseide
And to delyueren Antenor they preyde
O Iuuenal lord. ful sothe is thy sentence
That litel folkis wote what is to yerne
That the ne fynde. in hyre desyre offence
For cloude of errour let hem̄ to dyscerne
what best is / loo / ensanple here as yerne
This folkis desyren. now deliueraunce
Of Antenor / that brougħt hem̄ to myschaunce
For he was Aftyr traitor to the tovn̄
Of troye. Allas they quytte hym̄ oute to Rathe
O nyce worlde. loo thy dyscrecyon̄
Creseide wyche. that neuer dyde hym̄ scathe
Shal now lenger in hyr blysse bathe
But Antenor he shal come home to tovn̄
And she shal oute thus seyde here and hown̄
For wyche delyuerid was by parlement
For Antenor to yelden̄ oute Creseide
And hit pronounced by the presedente
Al-thogħ that Ector nay ful ofte preyde
What finially what wyght so it wythseide
It whas for nought. it was and shulde
For substaunce of the parlement it wolde
Departed oute of parlement echone
This troilus wyth wordes moo
In-to his chaumbre. spede hym̄ fast allon̄
But if it were a man̄ of his or two
The wyche he bade oute faste for to goo
Be-cause he wolde slepen̄ as he seyde
And hastely vpon̄ his bedde hym̄ leide
And as in wynter leves ben̄ berafte
Eche Aftyr other tyl the tre be bare
So that ther is but barke & braunche y-lefte
Lythe Troilus byrafte of eche welfare
y-bounden̄ in the blake barke of care
Disposed wode oute of his witte to breyde
So sore hym̄ satte the exchange of Creseide
He Ryseth hym vp and euery doure he shette
And wyndow eke. And tho this sorowful man̄
Vppon his beddes syde dovn̄ hym̄ sette
Ful like a pale. ymage dede and wan̄
And in hys brest the heped woo began̄
Oute to braste. And he wrought in this wyse
In hys wodenesse. as I shal you devyse
Rygħt as the wylde bole gynnyth to springe
Now here now there y-darted to the herte
And of his dethe Roreth a complenynge
Ryght so gan̄ he A-boute the chaumbre sterte
Smytyng his brestes. ay with his fystes smerte
his hede to the walle his body dovn̄ to the grovnde
Ful ofte he swapped hymself to comfunde
His eyen two for pitee of herte
Oute stremeden̄ as swyfte welles tweye
The sobbes of his sorowes smerte
his speche hym Rafte vnnethes mygħt he seye
O dethe Allas why nyltow do my deye
O-cursed be / that day that nature
Shope me to be a lives creature
But afftyr whan̄ Al this furye And this Rage
wyche that his herte twyst and faste thriste
By lengthe of tyme / somwhat gan̄ asswage
Vpp-on̄ his bedde he leyde hym̄ dovn̄ to Reste
But tho gan̄ his terys more oute breste
That Wondir is the body may suffice
To haue this woo wyche I you devise
Than̄ seide he thus fortune allas the whyle
What haue I doon̄ what haue I thus a-gylte
how myghtstow for Routhe me by-gyle
Is ther no grace And shal I thus by spilt
Thus shaɫɫ Creseide Awey for that thou wylte
Allas how maystow in thyn hert fynde
To be to me thus cruel And this vnkynde [St. 40 followes here in the MS.]

LG.HEAD: (39 : put as 40 in Harl. 1239)
LG.L: Haue I the not honoured al my lyue [Between lines 267 & 268, Harl, 1239 has, by mistake, a line made up of 268 & 269: "As thou wyl woste from Ioye thus me depryus."]
As thou [As thou in another hand?] wel wost / a-boue the goddes Alle
why wyltow from̄ Ioye thus me depryue
O. troylus what may men̄ / now the calle
But wreche of wrecches / oute of honour falle
In-to miserye in wyche I wole bewaille
Creseide Allas / tyl that my breith me faille

LG.HEAD: (40 : put as 39 in the MS.) [Late sidenote: This Stanza misplaced in Pynsons Edition.]
LG.L: Allas fortune in that my lyf in Ioye
Displesed hade vnto thy foule enfie
Wy nadestow my fadur kyng of Troye
Byrafte thy lyf or doon̄ my brethern̄ dye
Or slayn̄ my-selfen̄ that thus complen̄ and crye
I combre the worlde that may no thing deserue
But Alwey dye / and neuer fully sterve [See st. 39, which follows here in the MS.]
Ȝif that Creseide / allone where me lefte
Now Routħ I wyderward thou stere
And hyr Allas / than hastow me berafte
But euermo loo / this is thy manere
To Reue A wyght. that most to hym̄ is dere
To preue in that / thy grevyl violence
Thus am I lost thus helpeth no defence
O verray lord. of loue O god allas
That knowyst best / my hert and al my thought
what shal my sorowfulɫ hert / doon̄ in this cas
Yif I forgoo that so dere I haue bougħt
Syn ye Creseide. And me haue fully brougħt
Into your grace and bothe your hertis seled
how may ye souffre. allas it be Repelled
What shaɫɫ I don̄ .I shal whilles y may dure
On lyue in tourment And in cruel [peyne]
Thys infortune or this disaventure
Allas Allone ay as I was born̄. y-wys compleyne
Ne neuer wyl I see it shyne or Reyne
Ne see no lyght And thus in derkenesse
My sorowful lyfe wyl enden̄ in distresse
O Wery gost that errest too And froo
Wy nyltow flee / oute of the sorowfullest
Body. that euer myght. on̄ grounde goo
O soule lourkynge in this wrecchydnesse
Fle fourutħ oute of my hert and let it brest
And folow Alway Creseide my lady dere
Thy Ryght is now no lenger to ben̄ here
O woful eyen̄ too / syn̄ your disport
was al to seen̄ Creseides eyen̄ brygħt
what shal ye doon̄ / but for my disconfort
Stondyn̄ for nogħt And wepen̄ oute your sygħt
Syn̄ she is queynte. that you was wont to lygħt
In veyne from̄ this forth / haue I eyen̄ tweye
y-fourmed syn̄. your vertue is Aweye
O my Creseide. o lady souerayn̄
O that woful soule. that thus cryetħ
who shal now yeue / confort to your peyne
Allas no wygħt / but when̄ my hert dyeth
My spirit wycħ / that soo to you hyetħ
Receyuetħ in gre. for that I shal you serve
For now no force is / thogh the body sterue
O ye louers that hye vpon̄ the whele
Ben̄ sette of fortune in gode Auenture
Gode leue that ye fynde ay leue of stele
And longe mote ye. in Ioye endure
And whan̄ ye come by my sepulture
Remembreth that youre felaw Restetħ there
For I loued eke / thogh I vnworthy were
o [The initial letter is 1, but there is a small o by the side of it.] Calcas vnholsom And mysleved man̄
Calcas I meen̄ / Allas what ailletħ the
To ben̄ A greke sitħ thou art born̄ Troyan̄
O Calkas wycħ that wylt my bane bee
In cursed tyme were born̄ thou for me
As wolde blysfuɫɫ Ioue for his [his ocerlined later.] Ioye
That I the hadde where that I wolde in Troye.
a thosand sykes . hotter than̄ the glede
Oute of his breste / ecħ after other wente
Medled with pleynte / new his woo to fede
Therwytħ his wofuɫɫ terys neuer stynte
And shortly soo his sorowes hym̄ to-Rente
And wax so mate / that ioye ne penaunce
he felitħ noone / but lietħ forth in a traunce
Pandare wycħ that in the parlement
hade herde what euery lord and burges seide
And how fuɫɫ graunted was by on̄ Assente
For Antenor to chaunge soo Creseide
Gan̄ wel nygħ oute of his wytte to breide
So that for whoo / he nyst what he mente
But in a Res // to Troilus he wente
A certeine knyght / that for the tyme kepte
This chaumbre doure vndide hit hym anon̄
And pandare that ful tenderly wepte
Into his derke chaumbre / as stylle as any ston̄
Toward the bedde / gan̄ softely gon̄
So confuse / that he nyst what to seye
For verray woo / his witte was al awey
But wyth his chere and lokyng al to-torn̄
[Omitted in Harl. 1239. No gap for it.]
he stode this sorofuɫɫ Troilus beforn̄
And on̄ his pitous face he gan̄ beholden̄
And lord so often̄ gan̄ his hert to colden
Seyng his frynde in whoo whos hevinesse
his hert slougħ / as thougħt for distresse
This wofuɫɫ wygħt thus Troilus that Felte
his frende pandare / y-comen̄ hym to see
Gan as the snowe a-yenist the sonne melte
For wycħ this wofull pandare of pitee
Gan̄ for to wepe / as tendurly as he
And spechles thus / been̄ this ylke tweye
That neither mygħt a worde for sorwo seye
But at the last this wofull Troilus
For cruel hert / gan̄ bresten̄ oute to Rore
And with a soroufuɫɫ noyse he seyd thus
A-monges his sobbes / and sykes sore
Loo pandare I am̄ dede wythouten̄ more
Hastow not herde / in parlement he seyde
For Antenor / how lost is my Creseide
This Pandare ful dede and pale of hewe
Ful pitously / answerde / and seid yis
As wysly were it fals as it is trewe
That I haue herde at parlement how it is
And how ffor Antenor lost my Creseide is
who wolde haue wende / that in so a litel throwe
Fortune our ioye wolde haue ouer-throwe
O in this worlde / is no creature
As to my dome / that euer sawe Ruyne
Strenger then this thoro cas or A-venture
But who may alle ecchewe or diuine
Suche is this worlde therfore I this diffine
Ne trust no wygħt / to fynden̄ in fortune
Ay proprete her yiftes been̄ commune
But telle me thus / why Artow now thus made
To sorowen thus why lyestow in this wyse
Syn̄ thy desyre / al holy as thou hadde
So that by rygħt. it ougħt y-now souffice
But I that neuer fonde in my seruyse
A frendely chere or castyng of any eye
Lat me thus wepe and weyle tyl that I dye
And ouer al this as thou wel woste thiselue
This toune is fuɫ of ladys aɫɫ A-boute
And to my dome / fairer than̄ suche twelue
As euer she was shal I fynde in a Route
Yee two or three wythouten̄ doute
For-thy by gladde / myn̄ one dere brother
yif she be lost . we shul Recouure an̄ other
What gode for-bede / alwey that Iche plesaūn̄ce
In one thinge were and in non̄ other wygħt
What oon̄ can̄ synge / A nother can̄ wel daunce
Yif this is faire she that can̄ gode arygħt
Yif this by godely . thus is she gladde and lygħt
Eche for his vertue. holden̄ is full dere
Bothe heyroner and faucon̄ for Ryuer
And eke as wryte / Zanzis that was ful wyse
The newe loue / oute chaseth ofte the olde
And vpon̄ new caas / lyeth new a-vise
And thinke thy lyf / to sauen̄ art thou holden̄
Swycħ fyre of proces / shal by kynde colde
For syn̄ it is / but casuel plesaunce
Som cas shal put it oute of Remembraunce
For also sure as day cometħ aftyr nygħt
The new loue chasetħ labour or other woo
Or elles sielde / seyng of a wyght
Doon̄ olde affections / alle ouer goo
And for thy part / thou shalt haue oone or twoo
Tabbreggen̄ with thy bettur peynes smerte
Absence of hyr shal dryue hyr oute of herte
These wordes seide he for the nones Alle
To helpe hys frynde / lest he for sorow dye
For doutles to make hys sorowes falle
He Rougħt noutħ what vnthryfte he seide
But Troilus that nygħ / the sorow dyede
Toke litel hyede. of al that euer he mente
That oon̄ ere herde / At another it went oute
But At the last he Answerde And seid freynde
Thys lechecrafte or heled thus to bee
Were wele sitting / yf that I were A fynde
To traisen̄ hyr / that trew is vnto me
I pray gode lete / this counsel neuer thee
But do me sterue / Rather Anon̄ here
Or I so doo As thou woldest me lere
She that [that overlined later.] I serue what so thou seye
To whom̄ myn̄ herte inhabite is by Rygħt
Shaɫɫ haue me holy / heres tyl that I dye
What pandarus / syn I haue hyr byhygħt
I wole not been̄ / vntrew for no wygħt
But As hyr man̄ I wyl Ay lyue And sterue
And neuer other creature serue
And there thou saist / thou shalt As fayre fynde
As she lat bee / make no comparyson̄
To creature yfourmed hyr by kynde
O leue Pandare / in conclusion̄
I wole not been̄ / of thyn̄ opinion̄
Touchynge Al thys / therefore I the bescche
To holden̄ thy pees / thou sleest me with thy speche
Thou biddest me / that I shulde loue A-nother̄
As fressħly new / And lat Creseide goo
It lietħ not in my pouer leue brother
And thougħ I mygħt / I wolde not do soo
But kanstetow pleyn̄ / Raket to And froo
Oute netel in doke / now thys now that pandare
Now foule falle hyr̄ / that for thy woo has care
Thou farest eke by me thou pandarus
As he that whan̄ / A man̄ is woo be-goon̄
He cometħ to hym̄ / A pas And seitħ Rygħt Rygħt thus
Thenke not on̄ smerte / And thou shal feyle non̄
Thou must be fyrst / transmuen̄ As A ston̄
And Reue me my passyons Alle
Or thou so lightly do me woo to falle
The detħ may wel oute of my brest departe
The lyf so longe / may this sorwo myne
But fro my soule / shal Creseides darte
Oute neuer-moo / but doon̄ wytħ proserpine
whan̄ I am dede / I wyl goo lyue in pyne
And the I wole eternable compleyne
Thys whoo And how that twynned be we tweyne
Thou hast here made An̄ Argument ful fyne
How that it shulde / A lesse peyne bee
Creseide to for-goo / for she was myne
And lyued in ese / And in felicite
why gabbestow / that seide thus to me
That hym is worse / that is fro wele I-throwe
Than he had erste / noon̄ I-wele I-knowe
But sey me thys syn ye that thynke so lygħt
To chaunge so ay / in loue to and froo
Why hastow not / doon̄ besyly thy mygħt
To chaunge hyr that dothe the Al thy woo
Why nyltow let hyr from̄ thy hert goo
why nylthou Love / A-nother Lady swete
That may thyn hert / setten̄ in qiyete
Ȝif thou hast hade / in love ay suche myschaunce
And canst it not / from̄ thy hert dryue
I that lyued in lust & plesaunce
with hyr As moche As creature on lyue
How shulde I that foryet And that as blyue
O where hastow ben̄ hyde so longe in mewe
That canst so wele / and fourmable Argue
Nay pandarus nougħt wortħ is Al thy Rede
But doutles for ougħt / that may befalle
with wordes moo I wole be dede
O detħ that ender / Art of sorowes Alle
Come now sithen̄ / so ofte After the I calle
For Sely is that dethe / sothe for to Seyn̄
That ofte I-cleped / cometh And endyth peyne
Wel wote I [whil] my lyf was in quiete
Or dethe me slough .I. wolde haue yiven̄ hyre
But now [thy] commynge is to me so swete
That in thys worlde / nothing I so desire
O dethe syn with thys sorow I Am on fyre
Thou ougħt me a-non̄ / in terys drenche
Or wytħ thy coulde / stroke my hert quenche
Syn that thou sleest / so many in sondry wyse
A-yens her wylle vnpreyde day And nygħt
Doo me / At Request / thys servise
Deliuere now / the worlde than doost thou Rygħt
Of me that am / the woofullest whygħt
That euer was / for tyme is that I sterve
Syth in thys worlde of notħinge may I serue
Thus Troilus / in terys can̄ distille
As licour of lambek / ful faste
And pandarus. gan̄ holden̄ hym̄ stille
And to the grovnde / dovn̄ hys eyen̄ caste
But natles / thus thougħt he At leste
what parde Rather / than̄ my felaw dye
yit shalt som̄-what / more to hym̄ seye
And seide frende / sythe thou hast suche distresse
And sithen̄ thou list myn̄ Argumentis to blame
why nyltow thy-selfen̄ helpe to Redresse
And with thy manhode / letten Al thys grame
Goo Ravissħ her / ne canstow not for shame
And outher lette hyr / oute of tovne to fare
Or olde hyr stylle / and leve thys nyce care
Art thou in Troye. and hast noon̄ hardiment
To take a woman. wych that loueth the
And wolde hyr selfe ben̄ of thyn Assent
Now is not thys / A nyce vanite
Ryse vp anon̄ / and let thys sorow bee
And kyde thou Art a mon̄ for in thys hour
I wole be dede / or she shal beleven our
To thys Answerd hym Troy[lu]s ful softe
And seide parde. leve brother dere
Al thys haue I my selfe thought ful ofte
And more thing than thou devised here
And why thys thing is lefte thou shal wele here
And whan̄ thou me [me and an over∣lined later.] hast yeue an [me and an over∣lined later.] Audience
Ther-after maistow. telle al thy sentence
Fyrst sitħ thou woost thys tovn̄ hath Al thys werr
For Rauysshing of women̄ / so be myght
hit shulde not ben souffred me to erre
As it stont now or don̄ so grete vnrygħt
I shulde haue blame / as moche as Any wygħt
My fadres graunt yif I so withstode
Syn she is so chaunged for the tovnes gode
I haue eke thougħt so it were hyr Assent
To Axe of my fadur of hys grace
Than thynke I thys were Accusement
Syn̄ wol I wote I may hyr not purchace
For sith my fadur / in so hygħ a place
As parlement hath hyr eschaunge seled
he nyl for me hys honour bee Repeled
Yit drede I moste hyr hert to perturbe
with violence yif I do suche A game
[Omitted in Harl. 1239. No gap for it.]
hit moste be sclaunder to hyr name
And me were leuer deye than hyr dyffame
As nolde gode / but yf I shulde haue
Hyr honnour leuer / than my selfe saue
Thus am I lost for ougħt that I can̄ see
For certeine sitħ. I am hyr knygħt
I haue hyr honour / leuer yit than me
And in euery cas / As louer ougħt of Rygħt
Thus am I with desire And loue twygħt
Desire for to distourben̄ hyr me Redytħ
And Reson wyl not so my hert dredytħ
Thus wepinge / that he cowde neuer cese
He seide Allas / how shal I wreche fare
For wele wote I Alwey now my loue tencrece
And hope is lasse And lasse Alwey pandare
Encrecen eke / the causes of my care
So welaway. why nyl my hert breste
For while I lyue is litel hertis Reste
Pandare Answerde / frende thou maist for me
Doone As the list / but hade I hit so hote
And thin estate / she shulde goo with me
Thogħ Al thys tovn̄ cryed on̄ it be note
I nolde sette / Al that noyse at a grote
For when̄ men̄ haue / wel cried than̄ lette he Rovn̄
For whonder lastetħ / but ix nygħt neuer in tovn̄
Devyne not in Reson̄ ay so depe
Ne precyously / but helpe thyselfe anon̄
Bet is that other / than thy selfe wepe
And namely sitħ ye be bothe oon̄
Ryse vp for by hede myn̄ she shal not goon̄
And Rather by a litel / in blame founde
Than̄ sterve here As A knatte with-oute wounde
Hit is no Rape in my dome. ne no vice
Hyr to with-holden̄ / that thou louest most
Parauntere she may holden̄ the for nyce
To let hyr goo / thus to the grekys hoste
Thenke eke fortune as wel thy-self wost
helpith hardy man̄ / to hys Empryse
And fleeth from̄ wrecches for hyr cowardise
And thogħ thy lady. wolde a litel hyr greue
Then̄ shalt thyn pees / ful wele herafter make
But As for me / certein I can̄ not leve
That she wolde As now for euel take
why shulde than̄ / of ferde thyn̄ hert quake
Thenke how that parys / hath that is thy brother
A loue / And why shalt not thou haue a nother
And Troilus O thing I dare wel swere
That yf that Creseide. wych that is thy leffe
Now loueth the / As wel as thou doost here
Gode helpe me so / she nyl not take in greffe
Thogħ thou doo / but Anon̄ in thys myschyeff
And yf she wylnetħ / fro the for to passe
Than she is fals / so loue here wele the lasse
For-thy take hert / And thinke thus A knygħt
Thurgħ loue is broke euery law Alday
kythe now somwat thy coryage and thy mygħt
haue mercy on̄ thy self / for Any way
lat not thys wrecchyd / woo thyn hert gnawe [This line is repeated in Harl. 1239.]
But manly sette / the worlde on̄ syx And seven̄
And yf thou dye A martyr goo to heven̄
I wyl my seluen / be wyth the At thys dyde
Thogh I And Al my kyn vpon̄ a stonde
Shul in a strete As dogges lygge dede
Thurgħ gyrt with many A depe and blody wounde
In euery cas. I wyl A frynde be fonde
And yf the lyst here sterue As A wreche
A dieu / the deuel haue hym that Reche
This Troilus gan̄ with that worde quykyn̄
And seid graunt mercy Ich Assente
But certeinly / thou may me not so prechen
Ne peyne me may / so tourment
That for no cas / it is not myn̄ entent
At short wordes / thogħ I dyen̄ shulde
To Ravissħ her / but if herselfe wolde
Pandare answerd / of that be As it may
But telle than how / hastow hyrselfe Assaide
That sorowyst thus / and he Answerde nay
wher-of Artow / quod he thus Amayede
That noost not / if she wyl be evil paide
To Ravissħ her / syn thou hast not ben there
But Any Angil. tolde it in thyn ere
For-thy Ryse vp / As noght ne were A-non̄
And wassħ thy face / And to thy kynge thou wende
Or he may wonder / why thou art thus goon̄
Thou must wyth wysdom̄. hym and other blende
Or vpon̄ cas / he may Afftyr the sende
Er thou were ware / And shortly brother dere
Be glade and let me. werke in thys matere
For I shal shape it soo / that sykerly
Thou shalt thys nygħt / som tyme in som manere
Come speke wyth thy lady / pryuely
And by her wordes / eke and by hyre chere
Thou shalt fulɫ sone / parceuyn and wel here
Al hyr entent / And of thys cas the best
And fare now wele. for in thys cas I rest
The swyft fame. wych that false thinges
Egal Reportetħ / the thinges trewe
was thurgħ flede / wytħ prest wynges
Fro man̄ to man̄ / And made thys tale new
How Calcas dougħter / wyth hyr bryght hew
At parlement / wytħ-oute wordes moo
I-grauntede was / in chaunge for antenor
The wyche tale Anon̄ as Creseide
Hade herde. she with that of her fadyr thougħt
As in thys cas / Ryght noght ne whan he deide
Ful besyly to Iupiter / she besought
To yeue hym myschaunce / that this traitte brought
But shortly lest / these tales sothe were
She dorst of no wygħt / axen̄ it for fere
As she that hade her thought and al hyr mynd
On troilus by-sette / so wonder faste
That Al thys worlde / ne mygħt hyr loue vnbynde
Ne troilus oute of her hert cast
She wole been̄ hys / wyth that hyre lyfe may last
And thus she brenneth / bothe in loue and drede
So that she nyst / what was best to Rede
But As men̄ seyn / in tovnes al aboute
That women̄ vsen̄ / fryndes to visite
So to Creseide / of women̄ come a Route
For pitous Ioye / and wenden̄ her delite
And wyth hyr tales / dere ynogh a myte
Thes women̄ that in the Cite dwelle
They sette hem̄ dovn̄ / and seide as I shal you telle
Quod fyrst that oone / I am glade trewly
Be-cause of you / that shal your fadyr see
A-noither saide / ywys so nam not I
For al to litel / hath she wyth vs bode
The thirde Aunswerde / I hope ywys that she
Shal bringe vs / to pees on̄ euery side
That whan she gothe / Almyghty gode hyr gyde
Tho wordes / and tho womannyssh thinges
She herde as thogħ / she thennes were
For Al thys whyle / her hert on̄ other thing is
Al-thogħ the body / sat a-monge them̄ there
Gode wote hyr aduertence / was elles-where
For troilus ful fast hyr soule sougħt
with-oute wordes moo / Alwey on̄ hym she thougħt
These wommen that wenden̄ hyr so to plese
A-boute nougħt / they gan̄ her tales spende
Swych vanite / can doon̄ her non̄ ese
As she that al thys / meen̄ tyme brende
Of other passion̄ / than̄ that thay wende
So that she wende / anon̄ Rygħt for to die
For woo and wery / of that companye
For wych no lenger / she myght restreyne
her teres soo / they gonn̄ vp to welle
That yafe signes / of the bitter peyne
In wych hyr spiritt /. was and must dwelle
Remembryng hyr / from̄ heven̄ in wych helle
She fallen̄ was / sith she forgotħt the sight
Of troilus and sorowfully the sygħt
And thilke foles / sittinge hyr a-boute
wenden̄ that she wepte and syghed sore
Be-cause that she / wolde from the Route
Depart and neuer pley wyth hym more
And they that hade / knowen̄ hyr of yore
Sey hyr so wepe / and thought it kyndnesse
And eche of hem / wept eke for hyr distresse
And besyly / they gon̄ hyr conforten̄
Of thinge gode wote / that she ful litel thoght
And wyth hyr / wordes wenden̄ hyr disporten̄
And to be glade / ful often̄ hyr by-sought
But wych an ese / ther-wyth they hyr wrought
Ryght as a man̄. is esed to fele
For Ache of hede / to clawe hym on the hele
But aftyr Al thys nyce vanite
They token̄ hyr leue / and whome wenten̄ alle
Creseide ful of sorowful pitee
Into the chaumbre / vp wente the halle
And on̄ hyr bede / for dede she gan̄ to falle
In purpos there / neuer for to Ryse
And thus she wrought As I shal you devise

LG.HEAD: (106) [St. 108 'The salt terys' follows here in the MS., leaf 41, foot.]
LG.L: Here clere Here / that sonnyssħ was of hewe
She Rente / And eke her longe fyngres smale
She wrange ful ofte / And bade on̄ hyr Rewe
And with the dethe / doo bote on̄ hir bale
Hyr hew whylom brygħt / that tho was pale
Bare wyttenesse of hyr wo And hir constreynt
And thus she spake sobbynge in hir compleynt
Allas quod she / oute of hys Regyon̄
I wooful wreche / and infortuned wygħt
And born̄ in cursed constillacion̄
Mote goon̄ / And thus departen̄ from̄ my knygħt
woo worth that day / And namly that nygħt
On̄ wych I saw hym / fyrst with eyen tweyn̄
That causeth me / and Ich hym al thys peyne
The salt terys / from̄ heyen̄ tweyn̄
Oute Ronne / as shour in Apryl swytħ
Hyr whyte brest / she bette and for the peyne
Afftyr the deyth / she cryed A thousande sithe
Syn that he wonte / was hyr woo to lieth
She must forgoon̄ / for suche disauenture
She hielde herself / a forlost creature [Sce St. 106.]
What shal he doon̄ / what shal I doo Also
How shal I lyue / yif that from̄ hym̄ I twynne
A dere hert eke / that I loue soo
whoo shal that sorow / sleen̄ that ye been̄ inne
O calcas fadyr / thyn be Al thys synne
And cursed bee that day wych that Agryue
Me of hyr body / bare to been̄ a-lyue
To what fyn shulde I / lyue And sorowen̄ thus
How shulde a fyssħ / with-oute water dure
what is Creseide worth from̄ Troilus
how shul A plaunte / or other creature
lyue wyth-oute / hys kynde nature
For wych ful ofte / a byworde here I seye
That erthles / mote gryne soone deye
I shal doo thus / sitħ neither swerde ne darte
Dare I noon̄ handle / for the cruelte
That ylke day / I shal from you departe
yif sorow of that / nyl not my bane be
There shal no mete / or drynke come in me
Tyl I my soule / oute of my brest vnbrethe
And thus my-seluen̄ / wol I doo to dethe
And Troilus my clothes euerychone
Shullen̄ blake bee / in tokenyng hert swete
That I am as oute / of thy world ygoon̄
That wont was you / to holden̄ in quiete
And of myn ordre / til that dethe me mete
The obseruaunce / euer in your Absence
Shal sorow bee / compleynt And Abstinence
Myn hert And eke / the wooful gost therinne
Bequethe I / wyth youre spirit to compleyne
Eternally / for they shul neuer twynne
For theight in erthe / twynned be we tweyne
Yit in the fielde / of pitee oute of peyne
There pluto Reyneth / shal we been in fere
As Orpheus / wyth erudices fere
Thus hert myn / for Antenor Allas
I soone shal be yolden̄ as I weyne
But how shuld ye doon̄ / in thys wooful cas
how shal your tendur hert thys sustene
But hert myn̄ / for-yete sorow And tene
And me Also / for sothely for to sey
Soo yee welfare / I reche not for to dey
How myght it euer Al Redde been̄ or ysonge
The pleinte that she / made in hyr distresse
I not / but As for me my litel tonge
yif I discreven̄ wolde / her hevinesse
hit shulde make / her sorow seme lesse
Than that it was / And chyldysshly deface
her hygħ compleinte / And therfore I it pace
PAndare Wycħ / that sent from Troilus
Was to Creseide as ye han herde deuyse
That for the best /. it was Accorded thus
And he ful glade / to doon̄ hym thys seruyse
Vnto Creseide / in A ful secre wyse
There she lay / in tourment and in Rage
Cam her to telle / holy hys message
And fonde that she her-seluen̄ gan̄ to trete
Ful pitously / for hyr salt terys
Hyr brest hyr face / I-bathed was ful wete
The myghty tresses / of hyr sonnyasħ heres
Vnbreden̄ hanggyn / al aboute hyr eres
wych yafe hym signal matere
Of dethe / wych that woo she gan̄ desire
Whan she hym sagħ / she gan̄ for shame a-non̄
Her ytery face / a-twyx hyr Armes / hyde
For wyche / thys pandare is so woobegon̄
That in chaumbre / he myght vnnethe Abyde
As he that pitee felte on euery syde
For yif Creseide / hade erst complened hyr sore
Tho gan̄ she pleyn̄ / a thousande tymes more
And in hyr aspre / pleynte thus she seide
Myn Eme pandare / of Ioyes moo than woo
was causing first to me Creseide
That now transmued / ben̄ in cruel woo
wheyther shal I say welcome or noo
That Althyrfyrst / me brought in-to seruyse
Of loue / Allas that endith in suche wyse
Endith than loue in woo / ye ar men̄ lieth
And euery worldes Ioye As thynketh me
Thende of blisse / ay sorow it occupieth
And who so troweth not / that it so be
lete hym vpon̄ / me wooful wreche see
That my selfe hate / And ay my birth Acurse
Felyng Alwey fro wyk I goo to worse
Who-so me seyth / seeth sorow al at onys
Peyne tourment pleinte woo distresse
Oute of my sorowful body / harme ther non̄ is
As Anguyssh langour / cruel bitternesse
A-noye smerte / drede furye And eke sikenesse
I trowe ywys / from heuen teres Reyen
For pitee of my Aspre And cruel peyne
And thow my suster / ful of disconfort
Quod pandarus what thenkyst
why nastow to thyself som Resport
Why wyltow thus / Allas thyself for-doo
Leue Al thys werke / And take now hedde too
What I shal sey / And herkyn of gode entent
Thys that by me / thy Troilus the sente
Tourned hir tho Creseide A woo makyng
Soo gret that it / A dethe was for to see
Allas quod she / what wordes may ye brynge
what wyl my dere hert sey to me
wych that I drede / more to see
wyl ye haue pleynt / or terys or y wende
I haue ynogh / yif ther After sende
She was Ryght such / to seen̄ in hir visage
As is that wyght / that men̄ on̄ bere bynde
hyr face like / of paradise thymage
whas al y-chaunged in-to a-nother kynde
The pleye the laugħter / that men̄ was wont to fynde
In hyr and other Ioyes euerychon̄
Ben̄ flede And thus for hem she lieth Allone
Aboute hir eyne twoo a purpur Rynge
Be-trente in sothfastenes / tokenynge of hyr peyne
That to be-holde / it was A dedlyng thinge
For wycħ Pandare / myght not Restreyne
The terys from hys eyen̄ for to Reyne
But natheles / as he best myght he seyde
From Troilus / thes wordes to Creseide
LOs nece I trowe wele / ye han herde al how
The kynge with outher / lordes for the best
hathe made thys chaunge / of.Antenor And you
That cause is of / thys woo and thys vnrest
But how thys cas / Dothe Troilus maleste
That may not wordly / mannes tonge sey
As he that shortly / shapyth hym to dey
For wych we han / so sorowed he And I
That in-to litel / bothe it hade vs slawe
But thurgh my counseyl / thys day finially
He somwat hath / fro weping hym with-drawe
And semeth me / that he desireth fawe
Wyth you to been̄ / Al nyght for to devise
Remedie of this / yif there were in Any wyse
This short And pleyn̄ / the effect of my message
And eke the best As my witte may comprehende
For ye that been̄ / of tourment in suche Rage
May to no longe / prologe As now entende
And her-vpon̄ / he may hym answer And sende
And for the loue of god / my nece dere
So leue thys woo / or Troilus be here
Grete is my woo / quod she And sighed sore
As she that feleth / dedly sharp distresse
But yit to me / hys sorow is mochel more
That loue hym bete / than he hym selfe I gesse
Allas for me / hath he sucħ hevinesse
Kan̄ he for me / so pitously compleyne
y-wys hys sorow / doubleth Al my peyne
Greuous for me / gode wote is for to twynne
Quod she / but yit it harder is to me
To seen̄ hym in that woo / that he is inne
For wyl I wote / it wyl my bane bee
And dye I wyl / in certeine quod she
But hym come / or dethe thus me thretitħ
Dryue oute that goost / wycħe in my hert betitħ
Thes wordes seide she / on hyr Armes twoo
Ful gruf / And gan to wepen̄ pitously
Quod Pandarus / Allas why doo ye soo
Syn wel ye woot / the tyme is faste by
That he shal come / A-ryse vp softly
That he you naught / be-wepen thus fynde
But he wyl han hym / wode oute of hys mynde
For wyst he that / ye ferde in thys manere
he wolde hym-self slee / And yif I wende
To han thys fare / he shulde not come here
For Al the golde that P[r]yam may dispende
For to what fyn / he wolde A-non̄ pretende
That wote I wele · And therfore yit I sey
lat be thys sorow or platly / he wole dey
And shapith you thus / sorow for to a-brege
And not to encrece / O leef nece dere
And beyth to hym Rather / cause of flat than egge
And wyth som wysdom / ye hys sorow bete
What helpith it / to wepen ful A strete
Or thogħ ye bothe / in salt terys drent
Bet is a tyme / of cure than of pleynt
I meen thys / whan I hym Hyder Bringe
Syn ye been wyse and bothe of Assent
Soo shapith how / to distourbe thys goyng
Or come A-yen̄ / soone After ye been̄ went
women bene wyse / of short A-visement
And lat see now / how shal your wytte A-vaylle
And that / that I can̄ helpe / yt shal not faille
Goo quod Creseide and Vncle trewly
I wyl doon̄ Al my myght me to Restreyne
For weping in hys sigħt And bysily
Hym for to glade .I shal doo al my peyne
And in myn hert / seken̄ euery veyne
Yif to thys sore / may be founden̄ salue
hit shal not lackyn / certein on̄ my behalue
[The large initial letter is B, but there is a small g by the side of it.] goth Pandarus And Troilus he sougħt
Tyl in a temple / he fonde hym Al Allone
As he that of hys lyue no more Rougħt
But to the pitous / goddys euerychone
He fast made hys compleynt And hys moon̄
Be-sykyng hem to sende hym other grace
Or fro thys worlde / to doon̄ hym̄ sone pace [Harl. 1239 omits from here to st. 156.]
[And shortely alle þe soþe for to seye [Addit. 12,044,]
He was so fallen in despeire that day
That vtterly he shope hym for to deye
For riȝhte thus was his argumente aɫɫ daye
He seide he nas but lorne weylaweye
For alle that comytħ comythe by necessite
Thus to be lorne it is my destenye
For certeynly this wote I wele he seide
That / for-sighte of dyuyne purveaunce
Hathe seene alle-wey me to for-gone Criseide
Syn god sethe euery thynge oute of doutance
And hem dispositħ þoroughe his ordenaunce
In hir merites sothly for to be
As they schal turnen by predestyne
But / naþeles who Allas schaɫɫ I leue
For þer ben grete clerkys many one
That / destinye þorouȝe argumentes preue
And some men seyne þat nedely þere is none
But þat free chois is ȝeuen vs euerycheone
O weylaway so slye arne clerkes olde
That I note whos oppinion I may holde
For some men seyne if god seetħ aɫɫ byforne
Ne god may not bene disceyued parde
Þen mote I fallen þouȝe men had it sworne
That purveaunce hathe sene to-fore to be
wherfore ·I· sey þat frome eterne yf he
Hathe wiste byforne or þouȝte eke as oure dede
we haue no chois free · as þese clerkis rede·
[For other thougħt nor oþer dede also [Addit. 12,044,]
Miȝte never bene but swiche as purveaunce
whiche may not be desceyued nevere moo
Hathe felid biforne with-oute ignoraunce
For it þere myȝte be a varyaunce
To writhen oute for goddis puru[e]ynge
Þere nere no prescience of þinge comynge
But / it were raþere an oppynyoun̄
Vncerteyne and no stedefaste for-seynge
And certes þat were an abusioun̄
That god schulde haue no parfite witynge
More þan we men þat haue doue-to-vs wenynge
But swiche an erroure vpon̄ god to dresse
where fals and foule wicked cursynesse
Eke this ys an oppinioun̄ of somme
That haue hir Toppe fulle highe and smothe y-shore
They seyne riȝte þus þat þinge is not to come
For þat þe pres[i]ence hathe seene to-fore
Þat is · schal come but they seyne þat þerfore
That it schaɫɫ com þerfore þe purveaunce
wote it / by-forne with-oute ignoraunce
And in this manere þis necessite
Retournetħ in his parte contrarie a-geyne
For nedefuɫɫ be-houetħ it not for to be
That þilke þinges fallen in certeyne
That bene purveide but nedely as þey seyne
Bihouetħ it þat þinges whiche þat falle
That þey in certeyne be purveide alle
[I mene as þouȝe I laboured me in þis [Addit. 12,C44.]
To enquere whiche þinge cause of which þinke he
As wheþer þat þe prescience of god ys
Þe certeyne cause of þe necessite
Of thynges þat to comen ben parde
As yf necessite of thynges comynge
Be cause certeyne of the purveynge
But nowe for I me nowȝte in swewynge
How the ordre of Cause stonte but wele wote I
That I bihouetħ þat þe bifallynge
Of þinges wiste before certeinly
The necessarie alle seme it not / þere-by
That prescience putt / fallynge necessarie
To þinge to come be it foule or faire
For yf þer sitte a man ȝonde on a see
Then by necessite bihouetħ it /
That certes þine oppinion sothe be
þat weneste or coneteste þat he sitt
And ferþere-ouere nowe ageynwarde yitt /
Loo riȝte so is it of þe parte contrarie
As þus nowe herken for I nyl not tarie
I seye þat yf þe oppinioun of the
Be sothe for þat he sit / þen sey ·I· þis·
That he mote sitten by necessite
And þus necessite in eyþer ys
For in hym nede of syttyng ys I-wys
And in þe nede of sothe & þus for-sothe
Þer mote necessite bene in you bothe
[But þou mayste see þe man sitt not þerfore [Addit. 12,044.]
That in oppinioūn̄ of his sittynge sothe ys
But rather for þe man sitt / þere byfore
Þerfore ys þine oppynyoūn̄ sothe y-wys
And I· seye you · þe cause of sothe of this
Cometħ of hys sittynge ȝitt / necessite
ys entrechaunged bothe in hym and the
Thus in þis same wise oute of doutaunce
I may wele make as it semytħ me
My resonynge of goddis purveaunce
And of þo thynge þat in erthe falle
By swiche resoun men may wel y-see
That þese þinges that in erthe falle
That by necessite þey comen alle
¶ For al̄l̄-thougħ þat for thynge schal̄l̄ come y-wys
Therfore as it purveide certeynly
Nouȝte þat it / cometħ for it purveide ys
Ȝitt naþeles by-houetħ it nedefully
That þinge to come be purveide truly
Or elles þynges þat purveide be
That þei · be-tyden by necessite
And þus suffisithe riȝte ynouȝe certeyne
For to distroye oure free choyce euere dele
But nowe ys this abusioūn̄ to seyne
That / fallynge of these thynges tempereɫɫ
ys cause · of goddys prescience eternel
Nowe trewly · þat is a fals sentence
That þinge to come schulde cause his prescience
What myȝte I wene yf I hade swiche a þoughte [Addit. 12,044.]
But god þat purveytħ thynge þat is to come
For that is to come and ellys nouȝte
So myȝte I wene þat thynges alle and some
That whilome bene be-falle and ouere-come
Bethe cause of thilke souereyne purveaunce
Þat for-wote alle withouten ignoraunce
And ouere alle this ȝitt / sey I more þerto
Þat / riȝte as whan I· wote there ys no thynge
Y-wys þat thynge mote nedefully be so
Eke riȝte so when I wote þere is a thynge
So mote it come and so by fallyng
Of thynges þat be wyste before that tyde
They mowe not bene eschewed on no wise syde
Then seide he þus almyȝti one in trone
That woste of alle this thynge the sothefastnes
Rewe on my sorowe or do me deie sone
Or brynge Criseide and me fro þis distresse
And while he was in aɫɫ thys heuynesse
Disputynge witħ hym self in thys matere
Came Pandar in and seid as ȝe may here]
O myghty gode / quod pandarus in Trone [Harl. 1239.]
Ey who saw euer / A wysman̄ faren̄ soo
Why Troilus what thinkestow to doon̄
Hastow suche lust / to bee thyn oone foo
what parde yit / is not Creseide A-goo
why lyst the soo / for-doon̄ thyselven̄ for drede
That in thyn hede / thyn eyen̄ semen̄ dede
Hastow not lyued / al thy lyue beforn̄
Wythouten̄ hyr / and ferd ful wele at ese
Art for hyr / and for noon̄ other born
hath kynde the wrought hir oonly for to plese
Canstow not thynken̄ / thus in thys wyse
That on the thys / Ryght As ther fallen̄ chaunces
In loue Also / ther come And goo plesaunce[s]
And yit thys my wonder most of alle
why thou thus sorowyst / syn thou nost not yit
Touching hyr goyng how it shal falle
Ne yf she ben hir-selfe / distourben̄ hit
Thou hast not yit Assaide al hir witte
A man̄ may al betyme / hys necke bede
whan it shal of / and sorowen At the nede
For-thy take hede / what I shal the sey
I haue wyth hir y-spoke / And long y-bee
Soo As accorded was / betwyx vs twey
And euermore / me thynketh thus that she
hath som-what in hir [hir overlined later.] hertis priuyte
Wher-with she can / yf I shal Ryght a-Rede
Stint Al thys thinge / of wych thou Art in drede
For wych my counseil is whan it is nyght
Thou to hir goo / And make of thys an ende
And blisful ynow [for Juno] thurgh hir grete myght
Shal as I hope / hir grace vn-to us sende
Myn̄ hert seyth certaine / she shal not wende
And for-thy putte thy hert a whyle in Reste
And holde thy purpos / for it is the beste
Thys Troilus Answerd / and sighed sore
Thou seyst Ryght weɫɫ / And I wyl doo Ryght soo
And what hym lyst / he seide to hym more
But whan̄ that it was / tyme for to goo
Ful pryuely hym-self wythouten̄ moo
Vnto hyr come / As he was wont to doon̄
And how he wrought / I shal you telle soon̄
Sothe is it Whan they gan̄ fyrst to mete
Than gan̄ the sorow / hir hertis for to twyste
That neither of hem other myght grete
But hem in Armes / hente And softe kyste
The lesse wooful / of hem bothe nyste
what forto doon̄ / ne mygħt A worde oute brynge
As I seide erst / for sorow And for sobbing
The wooful terys / that they letten̄ falle
As bitter were oute of terrys kynde
For peyne As / is lygne Aloes or galle
So bitter terys / wepte not thurgh thy Rynde
The wooful Mirra / written̄ as I fynde
That in thys worlde nys so herde And hert
That nolde han Rewed vpon̄ hir peynes smert
But whan̄ hir wooful gestes tweyne
Retourned been̄ / there as hem ought to dwelle
And that somwhat / to waken̄ gan̄ the peyne
By lenghte of pleynte And ebben gan̄ the welle
Of hir terys and the [the overlined later; and euen as I added at the end.] hertis vnswelle
And thus she lieth / wyth hewes pale and grene
That whylom̄ / was ful fair and fressh to seen̄
[Syon ·I· deie and mercie I beseche [Addit. 12,044,]
Helpe troilus and þerwitħalle hir face
Vpon his breste sche leide and loste speche
Hir woofuɫɫ spirit / frome hir propre place
Ryȝte witħ þe worde alle weye vpon po[i]nte to face
And þus sche liethe witħ hewes pale and grene
That whilom fresshe and faireste was to sene]
This Troilus / that gan̄ on̄ hyr beholde
Clepping hir name / And she lay for dede
with[outen] answere / And felte hir lymmys colde
her [eyen] trowen̄ vpward to hir hede
Thys sorowful man̄ / kan̄ now no manere Rede
But ofte tyme / hir colde mouthe he kyste
wher hym was woo / god and hym-selue it wyste
He Ryst hym vp / and streyght longe hir leyde
For signe of lyue / for ought he can̄ or may
Can̄ he not fynde / in no cas on̄ Creseide
For wych hys songe / ful ofte is welaway
And whan̄ he saugh / that specheles she lay
wyth sorowful voys / And hert of blysse Al bare
how seid how that she was / oute of thys worlde fare
Soo Afftyr that / he had hir longe compleyned
hys handys wrange / And seide that was to say
And wyth hys terys salt her brest be Reyned
And gan̄ tho terys / wypen̄ of And drye
And pitously gan̄ for the soule preye
And seide lord / that sette Art in thy Trone
Rewe eke on me / for I shal folowe hir soone
She colde was / And wyth-oute sentemente
For ought he wyst / And breith felte he non̄
And that was hym a prygnant Argument
That she oute of thys worlde ys goon̄
And whan he saw / ther was non̄ other won̄
And gan̄ hyr lymmys / dressħ in suche manere
As men̄ doon̄ folk / that shulde be leyde manere [for on bere]
And Afftyr thys wyth sterne And cruel herte
hys swerde A-non̄ / oute of the sheyth he twyght
hym self to sleen̄ / how sore that hym it [it overlined] smert
Soo that hys soule / hir soule folow myght
There As the doom̄ / of mynos wolde it dyght
Syn loue And cruel / fortune it ne wolde
That in thys worlde / nomore he lyuen̄ shulde
Than seide he thus / fulfilled of hygħ disdeyne
O cruel Ioue / And thou fortune Aduerse
Thys Al And som̄ / that falseley han ye slayn̄
Creseide / And syn ye can̄ doo me no worse
Fy on̄ your myght / And werkes so diuerse
Thus cowardly / ye shaɫɫ me neuer wynne
Ther shal noo detħ / me fro my lady twynne
For in thys World / Syn̄ he haue sleyn̄ Hyr thus
wyl lete And folow / hyr spirit forthe in hie
Shal neuer louer / sey that troilus
Dar not for fere / wyth hys lady dye
For certeine I wyl / bere hyr companye
But sith ye nyl not / souffre vs lyuen here

L.NOTE: [Omitted in Harl. 1239. No gap for it.]

LG.L: And thou Citee / wych that I lyfe in woo
And thou pryam / And brethern̄ Al in fere
And thou my modyr / fareth wel for I wyl goo
And Attropos / make Redy thou my bere
And thou my Creseide / swete lady dere
Receyue now my spirit wolde he seye
with swerd At herte / Redy for to dye
But as [as overlined.] gode wolde / of swought ther-wyth shabreide
And gan̄ to syke / And troilus she criede
And he Answerd hert myn̄ Creseide
lyue ye yit / And let hys swerd oute glide
Yee hert myn̄ y-thonked be Cupide
Quod she / And therwyth-Al she sighed
And he be-gan̄ / comfort hir as he mygħt
Toke hir in Armes twoo / and kyssed hir ofte
And hir to glade / he dide al his entent
For wych hys gost that flykereth ay on̄ lofte
Ayen in-to hir hert / al softe wente
So that at laste / as hir eyne glente
A-syde a-non̄ / she gan̄ hys swerde espie
And it lay bare / and gan for ferd to crye
And axed hym why he it hade oute drawe
And Troilus a-non̄ / the cause tolde
And how hymselfe / ther-wyth he wolde haue slawe
For wych Creseide / on̄ hym̄ can tho beholde
[Omitted in Harl. 1239. No gap for it.]
And seide O mercy gode wyche A drede
Allas how nygh / we were bothe dede
Thanne yf I ne hade / spoke as / grace was
Ye wolde haue sleyn your selfe a-non̄ quod she
Yee doutles / And she answerd allas
For by that ylke lorde / that made me
I nolde a forlonge wey / on̄ lyue han̄ bee
Afftyr your dethe / to haue be crowned quene
For al the londe / the sonne shyneth shene
But wyth the selfe swerde / wych that here is
My selfe I wolde / haue slayn̄ quod she tho
But hoo / for whe haue Ryght y-now of thys
And lat vs Ryse / and streyght to bedde goo
And there let vs / speken̄ of oure woo
For by the morter / wycħ / that I see there brenne
Know I wele / that day is not for henne
Whenne they were in bedde in hir Armes folden̄
Nought was it like / the nyghtes here beforn̄
For pitously eche / other gan̄ beholden̄
As they that hade / for Ioyes alle y-lorn̄
Seying Allas that they were born̄
Tyl at the last / thys wooful wyght Creseide
To troilus / thes ylke wordes seide
Loo hert myn̄ wel wote ye thus quod she
That yf a wyght / alwey hys woo compleyne
And sekyth not / how helpen̄ for to bee
hit nys but folye / And encres of peyne
Syn̄ that here / assembled be we tweyne
To fynde boute of woo / that we ben̄ Inne
hit were Also tyme sone for to be-gynne
I Am A woman as Wel I wote
And as I am A-vised sodenily
Soo wyl I telle / you while it is whote
Me thinketh thus / that neither ye ner I
Ought haue this woo / maken̄ skylfully
For ther is hert / y-nougħ for to Redresse
That yit is mys / And slen̄ thys hevinesse
Swych is woo / that we ben̄ Inne
For ought I woote / for nothing elles is
But for the cause / that we anon̄ shal twynne
Considered al / ther is namore a-mys
But what is thenne / A Remedie vnto thys
And that whe shape / vs sone for to mete
Thys al and som / my dere hert swete
Now I shal brynge / it wel A-boute
To come A-yen̄ / soone Aftyr I am goon̄
Ther-of am̄ I / no manere thinge in doute
For dredles / wythine a weke or twoo
I wyl been̄ here / And that it may be soo
By al Rygħt / and in a wordes fewe
I shal you wele / and hepe of weys shewe
For wych I wyl not / make longe sermon̄
For tyme y-lost / may not Recouuered bee
But I wyl goo / to Ryght conclusion̄
And to the beste / in aught that I kan̄ see
But for the loue of gode / foryeue it me
yif I speke augħt / ayens your hertis Reste
For trewly / I speke hit as / for the beste
Make here I shal A protestacion̄
That doutles / thys thing / that in effect I sey
Nys nat but to make you / my mocion̄
To fynde vnto / your helpe the next weye
And takyth it not / other-wyse I you prey
For in effect / what ye wyl me comawnde
I wyl it doo / for that is no demawnde
Now herkenyth me / as ye han vndirstonde
My wenddyng graunted / is / by parlement
So ferforth that it may not be wyth-stonde
For al thys worlde / as by my Iugement
And syn̄ ther helpith non̄ A-visement
As in thys cas / lat dryue it oute of mynde
And lat vs fonde / a bettyr way to fynde
To sothe is that / the [t]wynnyng of vs tweyne
Ful cruelly / oure hertis wolde a-noye
But hym be-houyth / som tyme to haue a peyne
That serueth loue / of he wolde haue Ioye
And syn I shal / no ferther oute of Troye
That I may Ryde / ayen̄ in halfe a morowe
hit ought the lasse / to causyn̄ vs to sorowe
Syn̄ that I shal not / so be hidde in mewe
That day by day / myn̄ one hert dere
Considereth now / that tyme it is of trewe
Ye may not faille / of myn̄ estat to-here
Or that trew be don̄ I shal ben̄ here
And thus haue ye / bothe Antenor y-wonne
And me Also / beth glade now yf ye konne
And thynke Ryght thus / Creseide is now agon̄
But what she shal / come soone a-yein̄
And whan̄ allas / by gode Ryght a-non̄
Or dayes ten̄ / thys / aaufly dar I seyne
And that at erst / shal ye ben̄ so fayne
That I may haue / a liberte to dwelle
That al thys worlde / ne cowde our Ioyes telle
I seen̄ that often / ther as We be Ryght now
Of pourviaunce / our counseil for to hide
Ye speke not with me / ner I with you
In fourtenyght / ne see you goo ne Ryde
May ye nought ten̄ / dayes than̄ abyde
For myn̄ honour / in swych an Aventure
Ye mowen elles / y-wys / litel endure
Ȝe knowen̄ eke wele / that al myn̄ kyn̄ is here
Al holy but yf it my fadyr bee
And eke myn̄ other thinges / al in fere
A namly my dere hert yee
whom I not leue for to see
For al thys worlde / as brode As it hath space
And elleys come I neuer oute of thys place
Why gesse ye / my fadyr in thys wyse
Coueiteth soo to see / me but for drede
lest in thys tovne / that folkes me despice
Be cause of hym / that doon̄ hath suche a dede
For what woote ye / what lyue ys that I lyde
And yf ye wyst / in Troye how wel I fare
Vs nedytħ not for my wendyng for to care
Ȝee seen̄ eke that euery day more and more
Men̄ trete of pees / And it supposed is
That men̄ the quene Eleyne shal Restore
And greykys Repairen / that is mys
So thogh ther confort non̄ but thys
That men̄ supposen̄ / pees on̄ euery syde
Ye may the bettur / At ese of hert Abyde
And yf that it bee / pees my dere hert
The nature of thys pees most nedys dryue
That men̄ must entercomne in-fere
And to and fro / Ryde eke And goo as blyue
As thykke al day / as been̄ fleen̄ from̄ an̄ hyue [MS. lyue]
And euery wyght haue lyberty to be-leue
where as hym best lyst wyth-oute leue
And yf it so be / that pees ther may be non̄
Yit hider though pees / ther neuer were
I mooste come / or whider shulde I goon̄
Or how myschaunce / shulde I dwelle dere
In hoste amonge / the grekys euer in fere
hit nyl not bee / and gode soo wysly Rede
My soule / as ye haue cause noon̄ to drede
Haue here a noiter cause yf it so bee
That of al thy thing / ne can̄ not you souffice
My fadir as ye knowen̄ wel parde
Is wolde / and olde is ful of couetise
And I Ryght now / haue founde a new gyse
wyth-oute nette / wherwyth I shal hym hente
And herkenyth now / yif that ye wyl Assente
But dere Troilus / men̄ seyn̄ that harde it is
The wol ful / and wheither hole to haue
This is / to seyn̄ / that men ful ofte ywys
Mote spende part / the Remanant to save
For ay wyth golde / men̄ may thert grave
Of hym that sette is / vppon̄ couetyse
And how I meen̄ / I shal you it devise
The moeble wych / that I haue in thys tovn̄
Vnto my fadyr / shal I take and sey
That Ryght for trust and saluacion̄
hit seynt is from a frende of hys or twey
The wych frende besyly hym gan preye
To sende Aftyr more and that in hie
while that thys tovn̄ / stant thus in Iupartie
And that shal bee / an̄ huge quantite
Thus shal I sey / lest folk it espied
Thys may be sent / by none but me
I shal eke wele / shewe hym yf pees bytyde
What frendes / that I haue on̄ euery syde
To doo the wrathe / of pryamus to passe
Towardys hym / and don̄ hym stonde in grace
Soo what for oo thing and for other swete
I shal hym soo / enchaunte with my sawes
That Ryght in heven̄ / hys soule shal he mete
For al Appollo / or hys clerkys lawes
Or calculing / availeth not thre hawes
Desire of golde / shal hye soule blende
That as me lyst / I shal wele make ande ende
Now yf he wolde ought / by hys shorte it preve
Yif thys be les / certeine I shal fonde
Distourben hym̄ / and plucke hym by the sleue
In myddys hys werk / or bere hym̄ fast on honde
That he hath not / the godes vndirstonde
For goodes speken̄ / in Amphilogies
And for oo sothe / they tellen̄ tweynty lyes
Eke drede fonde goddes / I suppose
Thus shal I seyn / and that is coward herte
Made hym a-mys / the goddes texte to glose
Whan̄ he from̄ Delphos / to the grekys sterte
And but I make hym / sone to conuerte
And doo my Rede / wyth-in day or tweyn̄
I wyl to you / oblyge me for to deyne
And trewly I wrytte as I fynde
That al thys she seyd / of gode entent
And that hir hert / trewe was [and] kynde
Towardes hym / and spake Ryght as she ment
And that she starf nye / for who whan̄ that she went
And was in purpos / euer for to be trewe
Thus wryten̄ thoo / that euer the Iestes knewe
Thys Troilus / wyth eres and hert y-sprade
herde al thys thinge / devisen to and froo
And veraly hym̄ semede that he hadde
The same witte / but yit to let hyr goo
hys hert mys / foryaf hym euermoo
But finially / he gan̄ hys hert wrest
To trusten̄ hir / And toke hit for the best
The wych the grete furye of hys penaunce
Was queynt wyth hope / and therwyth hem̄ betwene
Be-gan for Ioye / thamarouse daunce
And as the birdes / whan the sone is shyne
Deliten̄ in hyr songe / a-monge the leues grene
Ryght soo the wordes / that they spaken in fere
Delited hem̄ / and hir hertis clere
But nathles / thys wendyng of Creseide
For al thys worlde / ne may oute of hys mynde
For qwych ful ofte / he pitously hir preyde
That of hir heest he myght her trewe fynde
And seide certes yif ye be vnkynde
And but ye come / at the day sette in Troye
Shal I neuer / as in thys worlde haue Ioye
For Also sothe / as sonne vpryst on̄ morowe
And gode soo wysly / thou me wooful wreche
To reste brynge / oute of thys cruel sorow
I wyl my selfen̄ [sle] / yf that ye drecche
But of my dethe / though litel be to Recche
Yit or that ye me causyn̄ so to smerte
So Dwellen here / myn̄ one dere hert
For trewly / myn̄ one lady dere
The sleightes yit / that I haue herde you stere
Ful shaply bee / to faille al in fere
For thus men̄ seyn̄ / that oon̄ thinketh the bere
But al anoither / thenkyth the leedere
Your fadyr ys wyse / and seide is oute of drede
Men̄ may the wyse / oute-Renne but not oute-Ryde
Hit is ful herde / to halten̄ vn-Aspied
Beforn̄ A crepul / for he can̄ the crafte
Your fadyr ys / in sleyigħt As Argus eyed
For Al be that / hys moeble hym berafte
Hys olde sleyght / is so yit so with hym lafte
Ye shal not blende hym / for your whoman̄hede
Ne feyne a-Ryght / And that is al my drede
I note yf pees / shal euer more betyde
But pees or now / for ernest or for game
I woote syn̄ Calcas / on̄ the grekys syde
hath onys ben̄ / And lost soo foule hys name
he dar no more come here ayen̄ for shame
For wycħ that wey / for ought I can̄ espie
To trusten̄ on̄ / is but A fantasie
Ȝe shal eke seen̄ / your fadyr shal you glose
To ben̄ a wyf / And as he can wele preche
he shal som greke / so preise And wel alose
That Ravissħ you / he shal with hys speche
Or doon̄ you doon̄ / by force As he shal teche
And Troilus on̄ hom / he wyl haue routhe
Shal causeles soo / sterue in hys trouthe
And vndyr thys your fadyr shal despise
Vs alle / And sey thys Citee is but lorn̄
And that siege / shal neuer a-ryse
For why the grekys / haue it alle sworn̄
Til whe be slayn̄ / And doon̄ your walles torn̄
And thus he shal you / wyth hys wordes fere
That ay drede I. ye wyl beleuen̄ there
Ȝe shal seen eke / so many a lusty knyght
A-monge the grekys / ful of worthinesse
And eche of hem / with witte And herde of mygħt
To plesen̄ you / doon̄ Al theyr besinesse
That ye shal dullen̄ / of the Rudnesse
Of vs sely / Troyans but yf Ruthe
Remorde you / or vertu of your trouthe
And thys to me / so greuous ys to thenke

ffor whiche me thynketh euery manere wight.
That haunteth armes oughte to biwaille.
The deth of hym that was so noble a knyght.
ffor as he drough a kyng by thauentaille.
Unwar of this Achilles thorugh the maille.
And thorugh the body gan hym for to ryue.
And thus the worthi knyght was brought of lyue.
ffor whom as holde bokes tellen vs.
was made swich wo that tonge it may nat telle.
And namely the sorwe of Troilus.
That next hym was of worthynesse welle.
And in this wo gan Troilus to dwelle.
That what for sorwe and loue and vnreste.
fful ofte a day he bad his herte breste.
But natheles though he gan hym dispaire.
And dradde ay that his lady was vntrewe.
Ȝet ay on hire his herte gan repaire.
And as thise loueres don he soughte ay newe.
To gete aȝeyn Criseyde brighte of hewe.
And in his herte he wente hire excusyng.
That Calkas caused al hire tariyng.
And ofte tyme he was in purpos grete.
Hymself like a Pilgrym to desgise.
To seen hire but he may nat contrefete.
To ben vnknowen of folk that weren wise.
Ne fynde excuse aright that may suffise.
If he amonge the grekis knowen were.
ffor which he wep ful ofte and many a tere.
To hire he wroot ȝet ofte tyme al newe.
fful pitously he lefte it nought for slouthe.
Bisechyng hire syn that he was trewe.
That she wol come aȝeyn and holde hire trouthe.
ffor which Criseyde vpon a day for routhe.
I take it so touchyng this matere.
wrote hym aȝeyn and seyde as ȝe may here.

LG.HEAD: (228) (Criseyde's Letter to Troilus)
LG.L: Cupides sone ensample of goodly heede.
O. swerde of knyghthode sours of gentilesse. litera Criseyde
How myght a wight in torment and in drede.
And heleles ȝow sende as ȝet gladnesse.
I herteles .I. sik I in destresse.
Syn ȝe with me nor I with ȝow may dele.
Ȝow neyther sende ich herte may nor hele.
Ȝoure lettres ful the papir al ypleynted.
Conceyued hath myn hertes pietee.
I haue ek seyn with teris al depeynted.
Ȝoure lettre and how that ȝe requeren me.
To come aȝeyn which ȝet ne may nat be.
But whi list that this lettre founden were.
No mencioun ne make I now for feere.
Greuouse to me god woot is ȝoure vnreste.
Ȝoure haste and that the goddes ordinaunce.
It semeth nat ȝe take it for the beste.
Nor other thyng nys in ȝoure remembraunce.
As thynketh me but only ȝoure plesaunce.
But beth nat wroth and that I ȝow biseche.
ffor that I tarie is al for wikked speche.

LG.HEAD: (231) (Criseyde's Letter continued)
LG.L: ffor I haue herde wel moore than I wende.
Touchyng vs two how thynges han ystonde.
which I shal with dissymelyng amende.
And beth nat wroth I haue ek vnderstonde.
How ȝe ne do but holden me in honde.
But now no force I kan nat in ȝow gesse.
But al trouthe and MS. and and alle gentilesse.
Come I wole but ȝet in swich disioynte.
I stonde as now that what ȝer or what day.
That this shal be that kan I naught apoynte.
But in effecte I pray ȝow as I may.
Of ȝoure good word and of ȝoure frendship ay.
ffor trewely while that my lif may dure.
As for a frend ȝe may in me assure.
Ȝet preye ich ȝow an yuel ȝe ne take.
That it is short which that I to ȝow write.
I dar nat ther I am wel lettres make.
Ne neuere ȝet koude I wel endite.
Ek grete effect men write in place lite.
Thentente is al and nat lettres space.
And fareth now wel god haue ȝow in his grace
This Troilus this lettre thoughte al straunge.
whan he it saugh and sorwfullich he sighte.
Hym thoughte it lik a kalendes of chaunge.
But fynaly he ful ne trowen myghte.
That she ne wolde hym holden that she hyghte.
For with ful yuel wille list hym to leue.
That loueth wel in swiche cas though hym greue.
But natheles men seyen that at the laste.
ffor any thyng men shal the sooth se.
And swich a cas bitidde and as faste.
That Troilus wel vnderstode that she.
Nas nought so kynde as that hire oughte be.
And fynaly he woot now out of doute.
That al is lost that he hath ben aboute.
Stood on a day in his malencolie.
This Troilus and in suspecioun.
Of hire for whom he wende for to dye.
And so bifel that thorughoute Troye town.
As was the gise Iborn was vp and down.
A manere cote armure as seith the storie.
Byforn Deiphebe in signe of his victorie.
The whiche cote as telleth Lollius.
Deiphebe it hadde rent fro Diomede.
The same day and whan this Troilus.
It saugh he gan to taken of it hede.
Auysyng of the lengthe and of the brede.
And al the werk but as he gan byholde.
fful sodeynly his herte gan to colde.
As he that on the coler fonde withInne.
A broche that he Criseyde ȝat that morwe.
That she from Troie moste nedes twynne.
In remembraunce of hym and of his sorwe.
And she hym leyde aȝeyn hire feith to borwe.
To kepe it ay but now ful wel he wiste.
His lady nas no lenger on to triste.
He goth hym home and gan ful soone sende.
ffor Pandarus and al this newe chaunce.
And of this broche he tolde hym worde and ende.
Compleynyng of hire hertes variaunce.
His longe loue his trouthe and his penaunce.
And after deth withouten wordes moore.
fful faste he cride his reste hym to restore.
Than spak he thus .o. lady my Criseyde.
where is ȝoure feith and where is ȝoure biheste.
where is ȝoure loue where is ȝoure trouthe he seyde.
Of Diomede haue ȝe now al this feeste.
Allas I wolde han trowed atte leeste.
That syn ȝe nolde in trouthe to me stonde.
That ȝe thus nolde han holden me in honde.
Who shal now trowe on any othes mo.
Allas I neuere wolde han wende er this.
That ȝe Criseyde koude han chaunged so.
Ne but I hadde agilt and don amys.
So cruel wende I nought ȝoure herte ywis.
To sle me thus allas ȝoure name of trouthe.
Is now fordon and that is al my routhe.
Was ther non other broche ȝow liste lete.
To feffe with ȝoure newe loue quod he.
But thilk broch that I with teris wete.
Ȝow ȝaf as for a remembraunce of me.
Non other cause allas ne hadde ȝe.
But for despit and ek for that ȝe mente.
Al outrely to shewen ȝoure entente.
Thorugh which I se that clene out of ȝoure mynde.
Ȝe han me caste and I ne kan nor may.
ffor al this world MS. word withInne myn herte fynde.
To vnlouen ȝow a quarter of a day.
In corsed tyme I born was weilaway.
That ȝow that doon me al this wo endure.
Ȝet loue I beste of any creature.
Now god quod he me sende ȝet the grace.
That I may meten with this Diomede.
And trewely if I haue myght and space.
Ȝet shal I make I hope his sydes blede.
O god quod he that oughtest taken heede.
To fortheren trouthe and wronges to punyce.
whi nyltow don a vengeaunce of this vice.
O Pandarus that in dremes forto triste.
Me blamed haste and wont art oft vpbreyde.
Now maistow se thiself if that the liste.
How trewe is now thi Nece brighte Criseyde.
In sondry formes god it woot he seyde.
The goddes shewen bothe Ioie and tene.
In slepe and by my dreme it is now sene.
And certeynly withouten moore speche.
ffrom hennesforth as ferforth as I may.
Myn owen deth in armes wol I seche.
I recche nat how soone be the day.
But trewely Criseyde swete may.
whom I haue ay with al my myghte yserued.
That ȝe thus doon I haue it nat deserued.
This Pandarus that al thise thynges herde.
And wiste wel he seyde a sothe of this.
He nought a word aȝeyn to hym answerde.
ffor sory of his frende sorwe he is.
And shamed for his Nece hath don amys.
And stante astoned of thise causes tweye.
As stille as ston a word ne kowde he seye.
But at the laste thus he spak and seyde.
My brother deer I may do the namore.
what sholde I seyen I hate ywys Criseyde.
And god woot I wol hate hire euermore.
And that thow me bisoughtest don of ȝoore.
Hauyng vnto myn honour ne my reste.
Right no rewarde I dide al that the liste.
If .I. dide aught that myghte liken the.
It is me lief and of this tresoun now.
God woot that it a sorwe is vnto me.
And dredeles for hertes ese of ȝow.
Right fayn I wolde amende it wiste I how.
And fro this world almyghty god I preye.
Deliuere hire soon .I. kan namore seye.
Grete was the sorwe and pleynte of Troilus.
But forth hire cours fortune ay gan to holde.
Criseyde loueth the sone of Tideus.
And Troilus moot wepe in cares colde.
Swich is this world who so it kan byholde.
In ech estat is litel hertes reste.
God leue vs for to take it for the beste.
In many cruel bataille oute of drede.
Of Troilus this ilke noble knyght.
As men may in this olde bokes rede.
was seen his knyghtehode and his grete myghte.
And dredeles his Ire day and nyghte.
fful cruwely the grekis ay aboughte.
And alwey moost this Diomede he soughte.
And ofte tyme I fynde that they mette.
with blody strokes and with wordes grete.
Assayinge how hire speres weren whette.
And god it woot with many a cruel hete.
Gan Troilus vpon his helm to bete.
But natheles fortune it naught no wolde.
Of oothers honde that eyther deyen sholde.
And if I hadde ytaken for to write.
The armes of this ilke worthi man.
Than wolde ich of his batailles endite.
But for that I to writen first bigan.
Of his loue I haue seyde as I kan.
Hise worthi dedes whoso list hem heere.
Rede dares he kan telle hem alle Ifeere.
Bysechyng euery lady bright of hewe.
And euery gentil womman what she be.
That al be that Criseyde was vntrewe.
That for that gilte she be nat wrothe with me.
Ȝe may hire giltes in other bokes se.
And gladlier .I. wol write if ȝow leste.
Penolopes trouthe and good alceste.
Ne sey nat this al oonly for thise men.
But moost for wommen that bitraised be.
Thorugh fals folk god ȝeue hem sorwe amen.
That with hire grete and sublilite. sic
Bytraise ȝow and this commeueth me.
To speke and in effect ȝow alle I preye.
Beth war of men and herkneth what I seye.
Go litel boke go litel myn tregedye.
Ther god thi makere ȝet er that he dye.
So sende myght to make in some comedye.
But litel book no makyng thow nenvie.
But subgit be to alle Poyesye.
And kis the steppes where as thow seest space.
Uirgile . Ouide . Omer . Lucan . and Stace.
And for ther is so grete diuersite.
In Englissh and in writyng of oure tonge.
So prey I to god that non myswrite the.
Ne the this mysmetre for defaute of tonge.
And red wherso ȝow be or elles songe.
That thow be vnderstonde god biseche.
But ȝet to purpos of my rather speche.
The wrath as I bigan ȝow for to seye.
Of Troilus the grekis boughten deere.
For thousandes hise hondes maden deye.
As he that was withouten any peere.
Saue Ector in his tyme as I kan heere.
But weilawey saue only goddes wille.
Despitously hym slough the fierse Achille.
And whan that he was slayn in this manere.
His lighte goost ful blisfully is went.
Up to the holughnesse of the seuenthe spere.
In conuers letyng euerich element.
And ther he saugh with ful auysement.
The erratik sterres herkenyng armonye.
with sownes ful of heuenyssh melodie.
And down from thennes faste he gan auyse.
This litel spot of erthe that with the se.
Embraced is and fully gan despise.
This wrecched world and held al vanite.
To respect of the pleyn felicite.
That is in heuene aboue and at the laste.
Ther he was slayn his lokyng down he caste.
And in hymself he lough right at the wo.
Of hem that wepten for his deth so faste.
And dampned al oure werk that foloweth so.
The blynde lust the which that may nat laste.
And sholden al oure herte on heuen caste.
And forth he wente shortly for to telle.
Ther as Mercurye sorted hym to dwelle.
Swich fyn hath lo this Troilus for loue.
Swiche fyn hath al his grete worthynesse.
Swiche fyn hath his estat real aboue.
Swich fyn his lust swich fyn hath his noblesse.
Swych fyn hath false worldes brotelnesse.
And thus bigan his louyng of Criseyde.
As I haue told and in this wise he deyde.

LG.HEAD: (1) (Proem: as the last Stanza of Book IV.)
LG.L: AProchen̄ gan̄ / the face of destyne [Teseide IX. i.]
That Iovys hath / in disposicion̄
And to you Angry / parcas Sustren̄ thre
Commytted to doon execucion̄
For wych Creseyde / mote oute of the tovn̄
And Troilus shal dwelle forthe in peyne
Tyl lathesys hys threde / no lenger twyne

LG.HEAD: (2) (The Story)
LG.L: THe goldetressed Phebus Hyght on̄ lofte [Teseide II. i.]
Thryes hade / al wyth hys bemes clere
The snowes molte / And Ziphirus as ofte
I-brought a-yen̄ / the tendre leues grene
Syn̄ that the sone / of Ecuba the quene
Began loue hir first / for whom̄ hys sorowe
was al that she depart shulde on̄ morowe
Ful Redy was at pryme dyomede
Creseide vnto / the grekys hooste to lede
For sorow of wych / she felt hir hert blede
As she that nyst / what was best to Rede
And trewly as men̄ in bokes Rede
Men wist neuer woman̄ haue the care
Ne was so lothe / oute of the tovn̄ to fare
Thys Troylus wyth-oute Rede or lore
As man̄ that hath / hys Ioyes eke for-lore
was waityng on̄ / hys lady euermore
As she that was / sothfaste Rote and more
Of al hys lust / Ioyes eke byfore
But Troilus farwel / now al thy ioye
For shalt thou neuer see hyr efte in Troye
Sothe is whyle he abode in thys manere
he gan̄ hys woo / ful manly for to hide
That wel vnneth hit seen̄ was in hys chere
But at the yate / there she shulde oute Ryde
wyth certein folk / he houed hir to abide
Soo woobegon̄ / al wolde hym not pleyne
Than on̄ hys hors / vnnethe he sate for peyne
For Ire he quoke / so gan̄ hys hert to gnawe
whan̄ Diomede / on̄ hors gan̄ hir distresse
And seide vnto / hym-self thys Ilke sawe
Allas quod he / thus foule a wrecchedinesse
Why souffre I hit / why nyl not I hit Redresse
Were it not bette / at onys for to dye
Than̄ euermore / in langour thus to drye
Why nyl I make it / onys Ryche or poure
To haue ynogh / to doon̄ or that she goo
why nyl I bringe / al Troye vpon̄ a Rore
Why nyl I slee / thys Dyomede also
Why nyl I Rather wyth a man̄ or twoo
Stele hyr awey / why wyl I thus endure
Why nyl I helpe / to myn̄ one cure
But Why he nolde / doo so felle a dede
That shal I seyn̄ / and why hym lyst spare
he hade in hert alway a maner drede
lest that Creseide / in Rumour of thys fare
Shulde haue be slayn̄ / loo thys was of hys care
And elles certeine as I seyde yore
he hade hit doon̄ / wythoute wordes more
CReseyde whan̄ that / she was Redy to Ryde
Ful sorowfully she syght and seyde allas
But forthe she moste / for aught that may betyde
And forthe she went / ryght sobrely a pas
Ther is non̄ other Remedy in thy cas
what wonder is / thogh she sore smerte
whan she forgoth / hir one dere herte
Thys Troilus in wise of curtesie
wyth hauke on̄ honde / and with a huge Route
Of knygħtes Rode / and did hir companye
Passing Al the wey / fer wyth-oute
And further wolde / haue Ryden̄ oute of doute
Ful fayn̄ / and woo was hym to goo so soone
But turne he muste / and eke it was to doone
And Ryght wyth [that] was Antenor I-come
Oute of the grekys hoste / and euery wygħt
was of it glade / And seide he was welcome
And Troilus / al ner his hert lyght
he peyned hym / wyth al is ful myght
Hym to wyth-olde / fro weping At the leste
And Antenor he kyssed and made feste
And herwythaule / he muste hys leue take
And caste hys eye / vpon̄ hyr pitously
And ner he Rode / and gan̄ hym cause make
To take hyr by the hande / al sobrely
And lorde soo she can̄ wepe tendrely
And he ful softe / and slyghly gan̄ hir seye
